recommendations: Perform CT Pulmonary Angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism given acute chest pain.
Consider pre-hydration with intravenous fluids prior to contrast administration.
rationale: Patient presents with acute right-sided chest pain, a primary indication for CTA PE.
The patient's eGFR of 59 mL/min/1.73m² is in CKD stage 3a, indicating a need for renal protection strategies.
Hypotension (MAP 59 mmHg) further elevates the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, necessitating caution and potential hydration.
Emergency admission and chest pain suggest a potentially time-sensitive diagnosis is required.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

protocol_selection.name: CT Angiography — Carotid Arteries (CTA Neck)
protocol_selection.description: CTA through neck using bolus tracking; triggered at specified HU in vessels.
protocol_selection.contrast_timing: Start when arterial lumen reaches threshold (~150 HU trigger).
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Adult: ~100 mL iodinated contrast at 4–5 mL/sec; pediatric: 2 mL/kg max.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Arterial studies have high contrast load; assess renal risk and consider MRI/MRA.
